context:
<Summary source="https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/01/1145997">
## Summary: Latest Mediterranean Deaths Highlight Need for Safe Migration Routes
**Source:** UN News | **Date:** January 29, 2024

### Key Facts & Statistics

- **Annual Mediterranean migrant deaths/disappearances (IOM Missing Migrants Project):**
  - 2021: 2,048
  - 2022: 2,411
  - 2023: 3,041 (by year's end)
- Three vessels from Libya, Lebanon, and Tunisia carrying **158 people** went unaccounted for in the prior six weeks; IOM recorded **73 people** from these "invisible" shipwrecks as missing and presumed dead.
- **62 migrants** were rescued off Cape Greco, Cyprus (departed Lebanon on January 18); several children were in critical condition, with one death confirmed.
- **Seven bodies** washed ashore in Antalya, Türkiye, believed to belong to a group of **85 migrants** missing since departing Lebanon on December 11.

### Named Source Opinions

- **Amy Pope (IOM Director General):** Called the numbers "a stark reminder" that safe and regular migration pathways are the "only solution" benefiting both migrants and states.
- **UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed:** Called for scaling up investment in Africa to meet SDGs and reforming international financial institutions to better represent African countries.

### Context
The article was published in conjunction with a one-day summit in Rome hosted by Italy, focused on African development and migration management, attended by 20+ African and EU leaders and UN representatives.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://etias.com/articles/eu-migrant-crossings-drop,-med-route-still-hot">
## Summary: EU Migrant Crossings Drop, Med Route Still Hot (Etias)

### Key Statistics

- **Overall EU irregular crossings (Jan–Apr 2025):** ~47,000 — down **27%** vs. same period in 2024
- **Central Mediterranean crossings (Jan–Apr 2025):** **15,718** — roughly flat compared to 2024; crossings rose ~40% in April due to improved weather
- **Eastern Mediterranean crossings (Jan–Apr 2025):** 12,200 — down 33% vs. 2024
- **English Channel crossings (2025 to date):** 18,100 — up 5% vs. 2024
- **Mediterranean deaths (Jan–Apr 2025):** The IOM reported **555 deaths at sea** in the first four months of 2025
- **Full-year 2024 Mediterranean deaths:** approximately **2,300**

### Humanitarian Context
- Despite lower overall crossing numbers, death risk persists; most fatalities occur on overloaded, unseaworthy vessels
- Smuggling networks remain highly organized, charging migrants €9,500–€13,000 per journey

### Policy Developments
- EU nations are expanding offshore "return hubs" (deportation centers outside EU jurisdiction), modeled partly on Italy's controversial Albania detention agreement
- Critics, including Statewatch Director Chris Jones, warn these hubs circumvent legal oversight and human rights protections

---
**Relevance to forecast question:** The article explicitly states **555 Mediterranean deaths were recorded by IOM in the first four months of 2025**, providing a direct recent baseline for comparison with the 1,000-death threshold being tracked for the same period in 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://news.un.org/en/story/2025/06/1164246">
## Summary: At Least Eight Drown in Red Sea as Smugglers Force Migrants Overboard

**Source:** UN News | **Date:** June 11, 2025

### Key Facts

- On June 5, 2025, smugglers stopped a boat carrying ~150 passengers in the Red Sea near Djibouti, forcing migrants overboard; **at least 8 are confirmed dead, 22 missing**.
- Five bodies were recovered near **Moulhoulé in northern Djibouti**; the death toll was expected to rise.
- IOM mobile patrols found many survivors in the desert; they are receiving medical care and psychosocial support at the IOM-run Migrant Response Center in Obock, Djibouti.

### Mediterranean-Relevant Data Point
- Separately, **10 migrant bodies washed ashore near Marsa Matrouh, Egypt**, believed to have departed from the Libyan coast — a common smuggling route across the Mediterranean to Europe.
- IOM's Missing Migrants Project reports **more than 32,000 people have drowned in the Mediterranean since 2014**, with an unknown number still missing.

### Eastern Route Context
- **272 people confirmed dead** on the Eastern Mediterranean migrant route (including Djibouti-Yemen leg) so far in 2025.
- Thousands of Horn of Africa migrants attempt the route to Gulf States via Yemen annually.

### IOM Response
- IOM called for stronger search and rescue operations and expanded safe migration pathways.

---
*Note: This article focuses primarily on the Red Sea/Djibouti incident; Mediterranean-specific 2025 year-to-date figures are not explicitly broken out beyond the broader 32,000+ cumulative statistic since 2014.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.context.news/socioeconomic-inclusion/in-data-a-decade-of-irregular-migration-to-europe">
## Summary: A Decade of Irregular Migration to Europe (Context/TRF)

**Key Facts & Statistics:**

- **2015 peak:** ~1 million people irregularly entered the EU — numbers have not come close since
- **2024 arrivals:** Down 38% from prior year; H1 2025 data suggests the downward trend is continuing, though the Central Mediterranean route has started to increase again after dropping in 2024
- **Central Mediterranean route** (North Africa to Italy) has been the busiest irregular route throughout the decade
- **COVID-19** caused an overall drop in arrivals, followed by a rebound in 2021 and new highs in 2023 (first since 2016)

**Mediterranean Deaths (IOM data cited in article):**
- **2023:** 3,155 deaths recorded — highest since 2017
- **2024:** 2,573 deaths — a decrease in absolute numbers, but the **death rate increased** according to IOM
- The Mediterranean is described as **"the deadliest migration route in the world"**
- Deaths on routes through Europe and from West Africa to the Canary Islands reached **record numbers in 2024**

**Asylum Trends:**
- Syrians historically received ~90% positive asylum decisions; most EU countries paused Syrian applications in late 2024
- Overall EU positive asylum decision rate fell to **24% in May** (vs. 50%+ in 2023–2024)
- Venezuelans have replaced Syrians as the top asylum-applying nationality in 2025

**Source reliability:** Thomson Reuters Foundation (high reliability)
</Summary>

<Agent_report>
Query: Retrieve IOM Missing Migrants Project year-to-date totals (dead+missing) for the Mediterranean for every year 2014-2025 through 30 April and any preliminary 2026 figures; list whether totals exceeded 1,000.
The objective was to compile, for every calendar year 2014-2025, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) Missing Migrants Project’s cumulative Mediterranean death-plus-missing total recorded up to and including 30 April, to note whether each year’s subtotal had already surpassed the 1,000-death threshold, and to provide whatever preliminary 2026 figure is available.  

1. Years for which a concrete 1 Jan – 30 Apr Mediterranean total is documented in open reporting

• 2014 – 96 deaths and disappearances up to 30 April (BBC News, 22 Apr 2015).  
 Exceeded 1,000? No.  

• 2015 – “More than 1,700 people are believed to have died this year so far” (reference date 22 April 2015, BBC News, 22 Apr 2015).  
 Exceeded 1,000? Yes.  

• 2016 – 1,855 deaths recorded by 31 May 2016; the 30 April subtotal is not given, but the figure necessarily exceeded 1,000 before May (UN News, 31 May 2016).  
 Exceeded 1,000? Yes.  

Those three items are the only instances found in the public domain that explicitly state (or allow a safe inference about) the Missing Migrants Project Mediterranean tally before the end of April in a given year. All other materials located either:

a) provide full-year totals,  
b) quote figures for different geographic aggregations (e.g., “Central Mediterranean” only), or  
c) stop at other cut-off dates (e.g., Q1, end-May, end-August).

2. Years with partial or route-specific early-year information that is insufficient for the 30 April, all-Mediterranean requirement

• 2023 – IOM cited 441 deaths on the Central Mediterranean route in Q1 (Euronews, 12 Apr 2023). The figure excludes the Eastern and Western sub-regions and covers only 31 March. Whether the all-route 30 April total topped 1,000 cannot be answered.

• 2024 – As of 17 September 2024 the Missing Migrants Project listed 1,450 Mediterranean deaths (UN News, 30 Sep 2024). No 30 April figure located.

• 2025 – IOM said at least 555 people died on Mediterranean or Atlantic sea routes in the first three months of 2025 (Guardian, 16 Apr 2025). The statement merges two basins and ends 31 March.

For 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022 no source in the retrieved material gives a Mediterranean-wide cumulative death-plus-missing number through 30 April.

3. Preliminary 2026 picture

• At least 606 people were reported dead or missing on the Mediterranean route between 1 January and 22 February 2026, making it “the deadliest start to a year since IOM began recording such data in 2014” (Guardian, 23 Feb 2026; Ground News aggregate, 24 Feb 2026).  
 30 April 2026 total: not yet published.  
 Exceeded 1,000? Indeterminate.

4. Consolidated table of substantiated data

Year | Mediterranean dead + missing 1 Jan – 30 Apr | ≥1,000? | Source
---- | ------------------------------------------- | -------- | ------
2014 | 96 | No | BBC, 22 Apr 2015
2015 | >1,700 | Yes | BBC, 22 Apr 2015
2016 | >1,000 (1,855 by 31 May) | Yes | UN News, 31 May 2016
2017 | — (no 30 Apr figure) | Unknown | —
2018 | — | Unknown | —
2019 | — | Unknown | —
2020 | — | Unknown | —
2021 | — | Unknown | —
2022 | — | Unknown | —
2023 | ≥441 (Central Med only, Q1) | Unclear | Euronews, 12 Apr 2023
2024 | — | Unknown | —
2025 | ≥555 (Med + Atlantic, Q1) | Unclear | Guardian, 16 Apr 2025
2026 | 606 (to 22 Feb) | Not yet | Guardian, 23 Feb 2026; Ground News, 24 Feb 2026

5. Key findings relevant to the 2026 forecasting task

• Documented evidence confirms that Mediterranean deaths exceeded 1,000 before May in at least two years: 2015 and 2016.  
• No reliable 30 April data are publicly available for 2017-2025, so the historical frequency of sub-May 1,000-death years cannot be fully assessed.  
• The 606 fatalities reported by 22 February 2026 indicate an exceptionally rapid death rate—roughly 11 deaths per day. Continuation at even half that pace would push the cumulative total beyond 1,000 well before 30 April, but the Missing Migrants dataset must confirm the actual figure.  

6. Information gaps that remain

• Exact 30 April Mediterranean death-plus-missing totals for 2017-2025.  
• Official IOM cumulative figure for 1 Jan-30 Apr 2026.  

To close these gaps—and thus deliver a complete historical series—access to the underlying Missing Migrants Project database (CSV download or API) filtered on Incident Date ≤ 30 April and Region = “Mediterranean” would be required; the published press lines and media reports alone do not furnish the needed year-to-date snapshots.</Agent_report>
